instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD1: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD1? PP2V5_NAND_SSD1 is a power rail that powers the soldered on SSDs.
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Hi have a weird problem, Received liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 16" the two left USB-C ports stay on 5v, 0,330A Upper on steady lower boot loops. The right ones go to 20v 0,107A both steady. When connected to either 4 <SIGNAL>USB_C</SIGNAL>  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> goes to 12,3V. Also received with a solder blob below F7001 connecting 20v to a test probe below it which is not in the schematic. See attached picture.
[ATTACH type="full" width="259px" alt="<SIGNAL>IMG_1736</SIGNAL>.jpeg"]60510[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full" width="257px" alt="<SIGNAL>IMG_1737</SIGNAL>.jpeg"]60511[/ATTACH]

After removing the solder joint the test probe measures 5V But can not lead it anywhere... Is the the rabbithole...

Also replaced both <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> on the left side with donor <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> which I reballed myself (I'm skeptical if I reballed them good) But after putting them back gave exact the same measurement as before. So nothing changed. Please help.

Measuerments:

PPBUS-G3H 12,3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3,3V

THXS

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings around <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips, between left/right channels.
You need to get 01700 board and check if that is just a test pad, or broken trace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Hi, checked diode mode readings around <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips left en right Found an OL on Pin79 UB300 USBC-TA-SBU1 on the left. On the right it was 0.625. So  changed the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> which I ordered new. Now boft sides give same results. But still 5v on left side and 20v on right side. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12,3v that should be 12,6v right? 

What can I Check more?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Yeah, 12.3V is incorrect voltage; no good communication between T2 and <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips.

Something more affected by liquid spill.
Inspect UB090 surrounding resistors and its traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 88122, member: 682"]
Inspect UB090 surrounding resistors and its traces.
[/QUOTE]

You where RIGHT again... It was RB281 which had a different diode mode measurement than corresponding measurement on right channel. Now all 4 ports give 20v 0.1a. But still getting 12.3v on ppbus. 

Tried to get in DFU mode to restore t2... But can't get it in DFU mode. (I know how, done it a bunch of times) Could It be that keyboard not working? Is there a way to to without keyboard. 

What more tips can you give me, You are spot on every time! This

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Remember that this machine requires 96W charger to boot; if no good battery connected.

You can use SWK003 pads, instead of keyboard; to force DFU mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:

I know about the charger. I always use the 96W charger...
Got to force DFU mode but came back with error. [ATTACH type="full" width="188px"]60563[/ATTACH] 

It feels like I'm olmost there...please advice further.

threads.message: Did not check, was assuming that first we had to have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> before anything else. Will check for ssd voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
If you can enter DFU mode, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is present.
Also check the G3S voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:

[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SSD0_SNS</SIGNAL>  3,3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SSD1_SNS</SIGNAL>  3,3V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0_SNS</SIGNAL> 12,3V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD1_SNS</SIGNAL> 12,3V
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> 0V 56ohm to ground
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> 0V 56ohm to ground

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_T</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
"L9080/81    424"
Diode mode reading from good board.
You should get a value in the same range.
You can't get exact same reading, but 56 ohm is really bad; points to damaged NAND.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Diode mode reading
L9080/81 397 

What does this mean? Is this the same range or to big a difference?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:

Diode mode reading
L9080/81 0.397
[/QUOTE]

This does not feel good...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Is normal; allow some time to discharge the remanent voltage.
Also disconnect the battery, before measuring in diode mode.

L9080/81 look good.
Do you get similar reading at L9580/81?
BTW, good enough to check one coil, when more connected together.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Hi 2 informaticos, Back after a long while again with this board. 
L9580/81 are same reading 372. 

I was checking booting sequence and all the rails are ok until I get to <SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> That one is missing... Looks like the PMU does not send Enable signal. Should I further investigate there?

Thxs again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
This must be T2 firmware issue.
Apple doesn't care at all about the problems generated by T2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message: Any more suggestions? What can I do next…

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
This is how Apple builds new machines.
You can try 100 times DFU and doesn't complete.
Then, after some days, weeks (maybe never), you may have luck and complete DFU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Ohh really?!? That really is shitty... So just keep on trying to restore!?


Another question, does DFU mode require a working Keyboard and screen. Because I received this repair only with topcase, without screen. And don't now for sure if keyboard is working.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
You can use SWK003 pads, without connecting keyboard.
Must connect charger with pads closed, then open pads after 3-10s; or when you see it on AC2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Wauwww, After months I the closet. I have an update... I flashed the T2 rom file just a hell Mary and connected on a battery with a charge in it and it is recognized as in DFU. After DFU restore I got an Apple logo.

Because it won't charge I can't complete the setup, to check for further problems (if any)

So looks like it will work on battery but now it won't charge.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with battery is 11.3V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> without battery is 12,3V

Amp meter on all ports 20v 0.100a with no batt connected
Amp meter on all ports 20v 0.030a with batt connected.

I have a working <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> But don't now where to start comparing... 

Feel like im olmost there

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:

Be sure to use 96/140W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Yes the battery works with a good board. And I use a 100W Not original but good Branded charger. Which also works with other good Board... Should this make a difference?!

Did some measurements. Think it has something to do <SIGNAL>WITHPPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> which is 12.3v on this board and should be 12.6V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
There is no good communication between <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and T2 (SMC).
That's the reason of incorrect <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and not charging battery.

Compare diode mode and voltage readings around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR>/70 between both boards.
Try changing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message: In diode mode, everything looked the same. I replaced the <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR> and the MacBook started to charging.  <SIGNAL>CHGR_BGATE</SIGNAL> with battery and power supply was around 12v all the time. Should I still replace the <TRANSISTOR>Q7070</TRANSISTOR> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Checked all diode mode readings for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> all are similar to working board. 

Also changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> stil same issue...

What else can disrupt communication between <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and t2? Could it have something to do with <CHIP>U4770</CHIP> SoC Rom? But it works with Batt so SoC rom shouldn't be the issue...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message: Also as you can read, this board had some issues before... Around UB090 USB-Rom chip. Could that have effected the communication with T2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Does the machine work with charger alone (no battery connected)?
All USB-C ports have the same behavior?

A problem with TBT ROM shouldn't allow charger to switch from 5V to 20V; on the corresponding ports (without battery).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
No, without battery doesn't work. Machine works on battery with charger connected but doesn't charge. 

I tried a SoC Rom flash. Didn't do a thing...
 
All USB-C port have same behavior...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
TBT ROM is involved, so may have a problem there.
Check traces and adjacent components for <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>/B090.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Before I look at the TBT rom area. I noticed that after I flashed the SoC rom with  the working one. It now stays in DFU mode. Even when I restore or revive it can’t complete and always stays in dfu mode… 

Also put back the original Rom file, can’t get it to boot with battery to anymore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message: Maybe the heat applied several times on the board affected T2, or CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Ok, got it back to working on Battery...

Need some help figuring out why ppbus won't go up to 12.6v

Feels like im so close!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
You can't get 12.6V with only battery.
What is <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage now (charger alone)?
What you've done to make it works again with battery?

The charger used (not original) works with good board without battery connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.25v charger alone. I did another dfu restore and it works with battery and charger connected. Amp meter shows 20v 0.1a. I bought original 96w Apple charger.

Charger works with good board perfectly.

Today I saw a Spanish video (used CC with translation) on YouTube [MEDIA=youtube]PIDIFer6Z4s[/MEDIA]

Who had same issue, and he changed all USB-C Controllers… and got PPBUS back to 12.6v.

I checked all pins of <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> with diode mode (easy job with S-UEM2 recommend to everyone! [MEDIA=youtube]IaTuD7A0MU8[/MEDIA] )

Maybe reflashing TBT rom?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
You can try reflashing TBT ROMs; make backup first.
Some peoples complain on Internet that <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips give problems on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> machine.
You may need to change them from donor board, same model.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Reflashing of TBT Rom's did nothing... 

The <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> are the original ones they are untouched! Maybe I can just compare in diode mode all pins of <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> with good board, I don't have to change all <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>?!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL>.
Also check the pull-up resistors on the corresponding bus (page 51).
Be sure to get correct voltage and diode mode to ground on both SCL/SDA lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Ok, weird enough all diode mode readings look good. But when I check voltage I see some weird stuff.

I checked <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> 0v
<RESISTOR>R5246</RESISTOR> 1=1.8v 2=0v
<RESISTOR>R5200</RESISTOR> 1=1.8v 2=1,4v
<RESISTOR>R5201</RESISTOR> 1=1.8v 2=1,1v

On working board all voltages are 1.8v So looks like something is pulling them down. How can I find out what is? 

I'm guessing one of the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>'s... But which one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
So actually what I see is
<RESISTOR>R5200</RESISTOR> is connected to other resistor <RESISTOR>R3021</RESISTOR> and RB241.
<RESISTOR>R3021</RESISTOR> is the going to <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> & <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.
RB241 is going to UB300 & UB400.

same for <RESISTOR>R5201</RESISTOR> is connected to other resistor <RESISTOR>R3025</RESISTOR> and RB242. 
<RESISTOR>R3025</RESISTOR> is the going to <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> & <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>. 
RB242 is going to UB300 & UB400.

Is it possible that disconnect <RESISTOR>R3021</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3025</RESISTOR> that will isolate <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>&<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>. Maybe if the voltages to <RESISTOR>R5200</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R5201</RESISTOR> will come back, at least I'll know which side the problem will be? Or do you think there is another way... or this won't work

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
T2 MUST talk with <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 and UB300/400; you can't isolate SCL/SDA lines.

If one <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> pulls down <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL>, will still keep it low if you separate its SCL/SDA lines from that bus.
Unfortunatelly, there's no way to isolate <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> from a single <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip.
You should compare diode mode readings around all <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips and also on J3300 and JB500.
S-UEM2 tester can help you...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
I tested all four <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips with diode mode... Every single point on them! (Hell of a job!) All 4 are same as know good board.

What I noticed is that <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> is 13 Ohm to ground when power is connected. So It looks like is being pulled down. When I look with thermal imager only thing which gets a little bit hot 29degrees is T2 chip.

When I got 1 <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip off, <RESISTOR>R5246</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R5200</RESISTOR> &<RESISTOR>R5201</RESISTOR> Got back to 1.8v! I got 4 working <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> from a donor a2141and TBT rom's. Changed all , but still same...

HELP!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> is 13 Ohm to ground when power is connected."
Checking ohm scale, or diode mode with power applied to the board???
Oh god; PLEASE stop doing that!

Just an idea; try removing <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips one by one.
Check when/if <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> goes high.
Input can't switch to 20V if one <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip is missing, but may help to locate the channel which pulls down the signal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
I tested while one chip was removed and then got 20v on the other side. And <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> was high... But doesn't this mean there is no communication between the chips. That's why it's not getting pulled down. I'm thinking as soon as the communication begins it's getting pulled down. With only 3 chips there is no COM.

I followed the link @tcampell34 [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php/CD3217_and_T2_Power_on_Sequence#820-001700_CD3217_Compatibility_issues[/URL] Where is said to change all <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> and TBT rom...

But still same... I'm running out of ideas

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
Put back that chip and remove another; from the other board side.
Check if same thing happens.

That is an interrupt request and can be activated (0V) at any moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 95779, member: 682"]
That is an interrupt request and can be activated (0V) at any moment.
[/QUOTE]
I don't understand this part...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ppbus 12,3v
threads.message: If any <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> detects a problem on its area, will pull down the signal; no matters there is communication (or not) on the corresponding bus.
